etymologies: mid 19th century. From an- + ancient Greek ἀλλαγματ-, ἄλλαγμα something given in exchange (from the stem of ἀλλάσσειν to change, exchange + -μα: see -oma) + -ic, after French anallagmatique

definitions: Of a surface or curve: not changed in form by inversion.

notes.text: Examples of anallagmatic curves are the cardioid and the Cartesian oval.

definitions: Of a tessellation in which the cells are of one or other of two colours: such that placing any two columns, or any two rows, side by side results in half the adjacent cells having the same colour and half having different colours.
